marklogic.body:
"Rewarding" was originally defined as "behavior reinforcing," and "palatable" is of course "tasty." But what do those terms predict?...That was never full established. Is palatable causing us to binge on the Spot or no? Do rewarding but unpalatable foods cause us to eat a little but then want more? Obviously the combination would suggest "overconsumption" short and long term. But, these things aren't inherent properties, and they are constantly changing for each single person, and also varying among people. Also Stephan himself should be clearer when using a term like "bland." To me that has no implied relation to rewarding.
Basically I think this is a big mess, because people are trying to consider it a "rigorous" scientific explanation to obesity/fat storage, when it is nothing more than an obvious observation and logical fact [some people binge; calories "matter"], which can play a part in a treatment plan. I've previously made the comparison to smoking addiction and lung cancer.
...So candy is rewarding, but if you eat only candy, it becomes "boring." I personally haven't eaten "junk food" in several months, but I can look at a pint of Haagen Daz and remember the goodness. Are its rewarding properties still lingering from a year ago? That seems unlikely, so it's the taste...but I thought palatability and reward could be disconnected? Why do babies Gain weight if they eat such a boring diet? Why don't lab rats get leaner and leaner since their diets stay the same?
...All of these "holes" can be easily explained by someone with a good understanding of physiology. But to explain things with physiological mechanisms would imply food reward hypothesis inadequacy. I think that's why we see terms like "reward system," "palatable," "hedonic," etc, instead of terms like "dopamine release." The only arguments that involve physiology are deceptive strawmen about insulin.
